Issues.Title: MethodInvoker Defined  in System.Windows.Forms and Reflection differently
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

The images are examples of a file using New MethodInvoker defined in System.Windows.Forms but Visual Studio does not think the include statement is needed (its grayed out) If you remove the Imports the program will fail to compile. 

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/12789369/25e869d1-f0e4-46c3-8130-d48c2f0b58b2)

If a function using MethodInvoker is copied Visual Studio will add an Imports to System.Reflection and says its required but it produces and error because System.Reflection does not have the needed New(AddresssOf x) overload.

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/12789369/15c911dc-d99e-417d-9942-08a3c5f3e384)


### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No idea

### Issue description

Use of New MethodInvoke is not handled correctly by Visual Studio, but I think it's due to a conflict between System.Refactoring and System.Windows.Forms which both define it with different overloads and System.Reflection is taking higher precedence.


### Steps to reproduce

Open ..winforms\src\Microsoft.VisualBasic.Forms\tests\UnitTests\System\Windows\Forms\ControlTests.vb
Remove the unnecessary Imports System.Windows.Forms and you will get errors compiling.

Cut and then paste a line with New MethodInvoker and Imports System.Reflection will be added, and code will not compile dues to ambiguous definition of MethodInvoker.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MethodInvoker Defined  in System.Windows.Forms and Reflection differently" (#9885)

Issues.Title: Fix Misdefined P/Invoke GetExitCodeThread
Issues.Body:
In .NET 7, we had gotten a report for WinForms application hanging on exit and found that due to changes to SystemEvent thread, it exposed a P/Invoke that was misdefined on our end. The fix for this has been serviced for .NET 7 (https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/9861). Although we haven't received a customer report nor do we have issues in the exact same scenario that we had gotten in .NET 7, given that the P/Invoke definition is misdefined in the same way and we are checking the error code it returns, issues around this P/Invoke being misdefined may resurface in other code paths.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/9883)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Fix Misdefined P/Invoke GetExitCodeThread" (#9883)

Issues.Title: The TreeView incorrectly scale on the high DPI devices in VB platform
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 6.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

The item text is cut inside the TreeView in high DPI.
See shortcut:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/23306796/087896e2-6c91-46cc-aba9-16860ca6eebd)
It works in .net framework 4.7 : (change the<TargetFramework></TargetFramework> from net6.0-windows to net47)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/23306796/4671c864-d903-4237-a2fd-4e9bec439c14)

The test code:
[TreeViewSample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/12574754/TreeViewSample.zip)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a VB form App(net 6.0) and place a TreeView. Fill in some content, for example, the paths under "C:\"
2. build the project
3. Set the DPI to 225%
4. Run the app
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The TreeView incorrectly scale on the high DPI devices in VB platform" (#9881)

2. Double click on any form to open it

Issues.Title: An System.AccessViolationException appears when changing InitialDirectory property of OpenFileDialog control
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET SDK 8.0.100-rc.2.23456.6

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, it cannot repro in .Net 7.0 SDK/.NET 6.0 SDK build.

### Issue description

After setting PropertyGrid's selectedObject to OpenFileDialog control and run the app, enter an absolute path to the D-disk for the InitialDirectory peoperty of the OpenFileDialog control,  an System.AccessViolationException pops up.

The issue also repro in FolderBrowserDialog/SaveFileDialog controls.

**.Net 8.0 result:**
[Exception Details.txt](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/12546662/Exception.Details.txt)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/56664234/686e9b60-6177-4134-b702-128f45af7cc5)

![repro_video](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/56664234/bce234e1-85d2-4730-a1dc-84c1c027e92f)



**.Net 7.0/.Net 6.0 result:**
There is no error dialog pop up and the InitialDirectory property of the OpenFileDialog control can be changed successfully.
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/56664234/31ce613e-b646-4da6-99b6-67a0ab494e97)

![Expected_video](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/56664234/de8aca08-95ff-454d-9453-515c50c006e6)

### Steps to reproduce

Use following sample application:
[WinFormsApp16.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/12546745/WinFormsApp16.zip)

Issues.Title: Fix folder browser code (#9866)
Issues.Body:
## Port of #9866

The old style folder browser was broken a few different ways:

- FolderBrowserDialog would not return the result
- FolderNameEditor would AV
- All were leaking shell handles

This adds a centralized helper to avoid these problems. This also:

- Moves the exception string to primitives
- Uses CSIDL defines and clarifies usage
- Unblocks other CSIDL values
- Uses the updated API to get the path from the PIDL

We can't use the shared dialog in FolderNameEditor as we expose dialog styles there that are not exposed in FolderBrowserDialog.

Fixes #9859

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/9873)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Fix folder browser code (#9866)" (#9873)

Issues.Title: Fix application hang on exit
Issues.Body:
Fixes #9721

`PInvoke.GetExitCodeThread()` is incorrectly wrapped. It doesn't define `SetLastError = true`, which causes `Marshal.GetLastWin32Error()` to not return the invalid handle error code that would terminate [this loop ](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/Control.cs#L3840) we eventually get into, ultimately causing WinForms app to hang on exit.

This is not an issue in .NET 8 as we are leveraging Cswin32, which defines PInvokes correctly.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/9861)

Issues.Title: Designer crashes System.InvalidOperationException: DPI mode value - DpiUnaware
Issues.Body:
### Environment

Microsoft Visual Studio Professional 2022 (64-Bit) - Preview
Version 17.8.0 Preview 1.0

### .NET version

net7.0-windows7.0

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

_No response_

### Issue description

I am using VS2022 for developing a Windows Forms app. Since i have a 4k screen i have a scaling of 150%. To keep my apps working on different DPI Scalings i have to restart visual studio everytime or set a registry key to disable the automatic DPI adjustment.

To do this, i use a registry setting: 

[Computer\HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\AppCompatFlags\Layers]
"C:\\Program Files\\Microsoft Visual Studio\\2022\\Preview\\Common7\\IDE\\devenv.exe"="DPIUNAWARE" 



### Steps to reproduce

The Issue was already well descriped in the following issue:
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/7609

If i remove the registry key and start vs with the /noscale parameter everything seems to work fine. 
But that's not working for the "recent projects" in the taskbar.

Issues.Title: Fix issue#9807
Issues.Body:
Fixes #9807

## Proposed changes

- Add Remove dependance on WebClient for VB FileDownload by using HttpClient
- Add a Visual Basic Scratch Project so that Microsoft.VisualBasic.Forms dependent code can be tested from a Visual Basic project (even an empty WinForms project written in VB does not work)
-  Upload still uses WebClient that also needs to be done as a separate PR

## Customer Impact
- Adds Async file download support to VB, and if WebClient goes away this will allow existing Visual Basic programs using synchronous File Download to still work.

## Regression? 

- Yes when WebClient if and when goes away, no today 

## Risk

- The code as is completely untested as I can't test without a working Scratch Project.
- The existing code uses ICredentials in some of the paths, it is unclear how compatible that is between WebClient and HttpClient 

## Test methodology
-  CODE IT UNTESTED, and don't know if any tests currently exist for FileDownload.
- I will write tests if none exist.

## Test environment(s) 
- TBD

<!-- Mention language, UI scaling, or anything else that might be relevant -->
- Visual Basic code to replace deprecated WebClient, before it is removed from .Net

Issues.Title: Fix folder browser code
Issues.Body:
The old style folder browser was broken a few different ways:

- FolderBrowserDialog would mutate the managed result string, usually corrupting memory in terrible ways
- FolderNameEditor would AV
- All were leaking shell handles

This adds a centralized helper to avoid these problems. This also:

- Moves the exception string to primitives
- Uses CSIDL defines and clarifies usage
- Unblocks other CSIDL values
- Uses the updated API to get the path from the PIDL

We can't use the shared dialog in FolderNameEditor as we expose dialog styles there that are not exposed in FolderBrowserDialog.

Fixes #9859

Issues.Title: When branding to NET9 is done, remove conditional compilation in System.Drawing.Common
Issues.Body:
Interop with GDI+ in System.Drawing.Common is done differently for .NET6 and .NET7+, so it is conditionally compiled using `#if NET7_0_OR_GREATER` in the code and conditional inclusion in the project file. This was required because the .NET8.0 version of the standalone package was [multitargeted ](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/1be42ac61d472f01dc6a2da06230b6e67e4cdfde/src/System.Drawing.Common/src/System.Drawing.Common.csproj#L3)to .NET6, .NET7, .NET8, netstandard2.0 and net472. NETFX version is a facade assembly, i.e. contains only type forwards. And the netstandard2.0 version does not contain [implementations](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/release/8.0/src/System.Drawing.Common/src/NotSupported.cs).  

The NET9 version will target .NET8, .NET9, netstandard2.0 and NET472, as these will be in support by the RTM time, so we will not need conditional compilation after branding is done.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "When branding to NET9 is done, remove conditional compilation in System.Drawing.Common" (#9863)
